description: Tania Singh "You don't have to compare horrible things to other horrible things. At all. It's a primal trap your brain uses to assess levels of threat when faced with potentially life threatening situations. And partisan hacks use it against you all the time.  Notice how when someone is murdered it is entirely inappropriate by everyone's standards to say, "Yes, it's awful what happened, but Hitler murdered 12 million people."  See how that's not useful, even if it's true?  Trying to diminish acts of violence and aggression by ranking them against each other accomplishes the following:  1. It sets a precedent for anyone contemplating abuse to keep their vile behavior just on the right side of outright condemnation.  2. It causes pain, embarrassment, and despair for the victim who already had to overcome a lot of self-doubt to come forward.  3. It sends a message to other victims that their stories won't be taken seriously unless it measures up to the greater of two assaults.  Resist the urge to minimize. Resist the urge to compare. It's not necessary, and is in fact hurting everyone."-  Lily Starling
